entries.longSummary:
One paragraph summaries

Sylvia Berryman argues that John Philoponus's 6th-century attempt to reconcile Aristotelian natural philosophy with post-Euclidean geometrical optics ultimately failed, but this failure reveals a significant defensive strategy used in late antiquity to preserve the relationship between mathematical sciences and natural philosophy. She demonstrates this through a detailed examination of how Philoponus tried to equate the geometrical concept of visual rays with Aristotle's theory of color actualities affecting a transparent medium, showing that this reconciliation breaks down on two critical points: first, incorporeal actualities present throughout a medium cannot account for the cone-shaped visual field and precise geometry of perspective required by Euclidean optics; and second, explaining the physics of deflection in mirrors requires treating them as receiving and retransmitting effects, which undermines Aristotle's claim that mirror images are observer-dependent and introduces localization problems inconsistent with actualities being present everywhere in the medium. The broader significance, Berryman contends, lies in how commentators responded to this incompatibility by asserting that "it makes no difference" which physical theory of vision one adopts—mathematical optics works independently—a strategy explicitly paralleled with "saving the appearances" in astronomy that reflects how all four Aristotelian "intermediate sciences" were flourishing by avoiding natural philosophical questions, creating tensions that would eventually contribute to the emergence of unified mathematical physics in the 17th century.

In her article, Sylvia Berryman's main conclusion is that the attempt by the 6th-century CE commentator John Philoponus to reconcile Aristotle's theory of vision with the more advanced geometrical optics of his time was ultimately unsuccessful. Berryman argues that this failure was due to two major challenges posed by later optical theories: the geometry of perspective and the physics of deflection. While Philoponus tried to equate the energeiai (actualities) of Aristotle's account with the opseis (visual rays) of geometrical optics, he could not adequately explain how immaterial actualities could account for the cone-shaped visual field needed to judge perspective and size, nor could he explain how they could be deflected by mirrors without undermining Aristotle's core ideas. A larger theme identified by Berryman is that commentators like Philoponus adopted an "insulation strategy," claiming "it makes no difference" (ouden diaphôrei) which physical theory of vision was used, thereby asserting the independence of mathematical sciences like optics from natural philosophy in an attempt to manage the growing conflicts between them.

LLM summary #1

Main Argument
Sylvia Berryman examines how 6th-century CE Aristotelian commentators, particularly John Philoponus, attempted to reconcile Aristotle's theory of vision with post-Euclidean geometrical optics. She argues this reconciliation ultimately failed, but reveals an important defensive strategy: claiming that mathematical models in "intermediate sciences" (like optics) are independent from physical theories of vision.

Key Points
The Compatibility Problem:
Aristotle's Meteorology uses optical geometry with an opsis (line of sight) that deflects from mirrors
His De Anima presents a different theory: vision occurs when colored objects actualize the transparent medium, affecting the eye
Post-Aristotelian Euclidean optics introduced a cone of multiple visual rays diverging from the eye—incompatible with both accounts
Philoponus's Failed Solution:
He claimed mathematical optics works regardless of whether visual effects go from the eye or to the eye ("it makes no difference")
He tried treating energeiai (actualities in the medium) as equivalents to visual rays
This failed because:
Incorporeal actualities can't explain the cone-shaped visual field or perspective geometry
Deflection requires physical explanation—mirrors must receive and retransmit effects, contradicting Aristotle's view
The account can't explain localization and directionality of vision
The "Insulation Strategy":
Commentators used the phrase "it makes no difference" (ouden diaphôrei) programmatically—far beyond Aristotle's limited use
This paralleled astronomy's "saving the appearances"—keeping mathematical models separate from physical explanations
Reflected broader tensions between all four Aristotelian "intermediate sciences" (optics, astronomy, harmonics, mechanics) and natural philosophy in late antiquity

Significance
The paper shows how mathematical sciences were flourishing independently while natural philosophy struggled to accommodate them—a dynamic crucial for understanding the eventual emergence of mathematized physics in the 17th century.

LLM summary #2

Berryman argues that late-antique Aristotelians—especially John Philoponus—tried and failed to reconcile Aristotle’s natural philosophy of vision with the post-Euclidean, geometrical optics of lines, cones, and mirror/refraction phenomena. Aristotle had classified optics as an “intermediate science” that studies mathematical relations in nature without full causal theory; his Meteorology explains appearances (rainbows, halos) via an opsis (line of sight) and deflection, but it sits uneasily with the causal account of vision in De Anima. Philoponus’ strategy is to reinterpret the geometers’ “visual rays” as Aristotelian energeiai (actualities) that are present throughout the medium and have direction of influence without any “travel.” He uses this to claim that, for the geometry, “it makes no difference” whether something goes out from the eye or comes from the object. Berryman shows this move breaks down on two fronts: (1) the geometry of perspective (the cone of vision and judgments of apparent size/distance) requires localized, converging structure that the “everywhere-present” actualities struggle to supply; and (2) the physics of deflection (especially mirrors and burning-glasses) forces Philoponus to treat mirrors as receiving and then re-emitting actualities—effectively making them sources—undermining Aristotle’s own view that mirror images are just “seeing by deflection.” She situates this within a wider late-antique “insulation strategy”: commentators generalize the slogan “it makes no difference” (paired with astronomy’s “saving the appearances”) to protect the mathematical success of the intermediate sciences (optics, astronomy, harmonics, mechanics) from conflicts with Aristotelian physics. The accumulating tensions, she suggests, prefigure the early-modern unification of mathematics and physics. 

LLM summary #3

Sylvia Berryman's article examines the attempts by Aristotelian commentators in late antiquity, particularly John Philoponus in the 6th century CE, to reconcile Aristotle's theory of vision with the more advanced geometrical optics that developed in the centuries after him. The article argues that Philoponus's integration of these two fields was ultimately unsuccessful because Aristotle's account is seriously challenged by newer theories on the geometry of perspective and the physics of deflection.

A larger theme of the article is the identification of a strategy used in late antiquity to insulate mathematical sciences like optics from conflicts with natural philosophy. Commentators claimed "it makes no difference" (ouden diaphôrei) which physical theory of vision was adopted for the purposes of geometrical optics. This approach is explicitly compared to the idea of "saving the appearances" in astronomy and is crucial for understanding the changing relationship between the "intermediate sciences" and natural philosophy.

The Initial Problem: Reconciling Aristotle's Own Texts
Aristotle classified optics as one of four "intermediate sciences" between mathematics and natural philosophy. These disciplines study the mathematical relationships in the natural world without offering complete physical explanations. For example, in his Meteorology, Aristotle uses ideas from optics to explain phenomena like rainbows and haloes, focusing on the geometry of how things appear to us rather than the physical nature of vision itself.

This focus on geometry involves the concept of opsis, a term that could mean the eye, sight, a visual process, or a "visual ray" emanating from the eye. The Meteorology describes opsis as something that can be deflected from surfaces, which has physical implications (e.g., it "stretches out" and "weakens" over distance). This creates a potential conflict with Aristotle's primary theory of vision in De Anima, which does not involve a ray traveling from the eye. In De Anima, color is said to change the transparent medium, and this change then affects the sense organ.

Philoponus's Attempt at Reconciliation
Centuries later, commentators like Philoponus faced an even more complex task. Geometrical optics had adopted the Euclidean model, which posits multiple opseis (visual rays) diverging from the eye in a cone-shaped array to explain perspective—why objects appear smaller from farther away. This was a significant departure from the single opsis model in Aristotle's Meteorology.

Philoponus attempted to bridge this gap by equating the opseis of geometrical optics with the energeiai ('activities' or 'actualities') from Aristotle's De Anima. His key claim was that it makes no difference to the geometry whether lines are drawn proceeding from the eye to a mirror (the optics model) or deflected from the mirror to the eye (the Aristotelian model). Philoponus argued for a "static" conception of these energeiai, suggesting they are incorporeal states or "actualities" present throughout the medium as a whole, rather than physical things that travel. Vision occurs when an observer's eye is correctly oriented along a straight line with the object.

The Failure of Reconciliation
Berryman argues that Philoponus's reconciliation fails due to two major difficulties: the geometry of perspective and the physics of deflection.
Geometry of Perspective: The Euclidean model's power lies in its use of a visual cone to explain how we judge an object's size based on the angle it subtends at the eye. For Philoponus's theory to work, the energeiai coming froman object would need to converge at every possible point from which an eye can see it, while still conveying the necessary information about size and distance. Philoponus acknowledges this difficulty, conceding that features implying size seem to be corporeal, which contradicts his idea of incorporeal actualities.
Physics of Deflection: Philoponus's incorporeal energeiai cannot be deflected by a mirror in the way a physical impulse could. To solve this, he and Alexander of Aphrodisias proposed that mirrors actively receive the energeiaiand then retransmit new ones. This is especially necessary to explain phenomena like burning glasses, where mirrors intensify light. However, this solution undermines a key aspect of Aristotle's view: that we see the object itself via deflection, not an observer-independent image in the mirror. If mirrors create new causal processes, then the resulting image becomes an independent effect, challenging Aristotle's account.

The "It Makes No Difference" Strategy
Berryman suggests that the phrase "it makes no difference" (ouden diaphôrei) was used programmatically by commentators to assert the independence of geometrical optics from physical theories of vision. This "insulation strategy" became necessary as the mathematical sciences flourished and their findings grew increasingly at odds with Aristotelian natural philosophy. Philoponus explicitly links this idea to "saving the appearances," a concept from astronomy, suggesting a parallel effort to manage conflicts between mathematical models and physical reality.

The article concludes that this tension was not unique to optics; similar conflicts existed in astronomy, harmonics, and mechanics. The strategy of insulating the intermediate sciences from natural philosophy was a response to the growing conceptual difficulties of creating a unified mathematical physics in late antiquity. This historical tension is a crucial factor in understanding the background to the emergence of a new, unified science in the 17th century.

entries.longSummary:
One sentence summaries


Bolton argues that Aristotle solves the problem of perceptual content underdetermination by requiring both the efficient cause (external sensible qualities acting on sense organs) and the material cause (internal phantasmic appearances with intentional content) to work together under normal conditions, thereby offering a naturalistic account of perception that avoids the explanatory gaps of purely materialist theories.


Bolton argues that Aristotle naturalizes perception by insisting it be explained through the integration of all four causes—where external sensibles provide the efficient cause but underdetermine content that is fixed by the perceiver’s material states (including phantasia)—all within a direct-realist framework about the objects of perception.


Bolton's article argues that Aristotle's naturalistic account of perception solves the problem of "underdetermination" by demonstrating that the content of a perceptual state is fixed not by the external efficient cause alone, but by the combination of that efficient cause with a specific internal material cause, which Aristotle identifies as phantasia or sensory appearance.


Human summary


Short summary: Defense of an intermediate position in the spiritualist/literalist debate. He argues that literalists have overlooked the significance of final causes for understanding what goes on in perception.


Longer summary:


Bolton attempts to navigate a middle way through the spiritualist/literalist debate, arguing that Aristotle thinks that a proper account of perception is required to utilize all four causes, not merely the formal or the material/efficient. So while the literalists focuses on the material and efficient, Bolton claims these underdetermine the perception, and so require as well a further (formal and teleological) cause in order to count as full perceptions: “The matter or material cause of a thing, for Aristotle, is only what gives something the potential for being that thing (Phys II.1 193b6-8, DA II.2 414a25-7). More is required to guarantee the actuality of the thing” (216).  [He hedges a bit about whether a formal cause without an efficient cause would be possible (spiritualism), but he thinks it would be possible only in weird cases, not as a general account.]


What is further required for the actuality of perception is the interaction with the the special sensibles and the intellect. We directly see the special sensibles, but this is only color; everything else requires some kind of inference (or awareness) by the mind: Aristotle’s “primary claim is that when I see a gold ring my senses are acted on by its gold color but not by its gold matter. So when I do see its gold matter this is not because I or my senses receive (the form of) its gold matter” (220). That is, when I detect the matter of the object by its color, I’m detecting an ‘incidental’ sensible by means of a ‘special’ sensible; or, put differently, the incidental sensible of detecting some conceptual property of the object (that Joe is Jim’s dad, or whatever).  So for perception to be complete, it must involve material (the eye), efficient (some object being perceptible), formal (the sensory-properties themselves) and intellectual, as the awareness of the scene:


I do not necessarily perceive even the special or common sensibles that are acting on my perceptual system in normal conditions.  Here again, then, even under normal conditions the external causal input taken alone can underdetermine the content of our perceptual states including all of our veridical perceptual states. 223


This means that the literalist reading greatly underdetermines what is required for perception: “We cannot see something, whether it be an eclipse or a color, without being aware that we are” (223). To put it in contemporary terms, we cannot see something without seeing that.  So even though we directly see color, the rest of the world is detected by the ‘seeing that’ of the mind’s awareness. Bolton ties this together with the notion of phantasia, which Aristotle says we employ even when we are engaged in veridical perception: “this thesis, that phantasia occurs during even our veridical perception and is required for all of our perception, veridical and non-veridical, is in fact quite easy to understand,” because phantasia should just mean the appearances of objects (something like the propositional-conceptual synthesis of the sensibles into something we can use for thought) (230). So while “what I see is simply the external object,” Bolton claims that “what I see is determined by what visually appears to me though the visual appearance is not itself what I see” (236). So while perception is entirely passive, the object I see is determined by the phantasia I bring to bear to determine it. 


Bolton concludes, then, by trying to separate how his account is distinct from a sense-datum account. Specifically, he argues that for Aristotle we do not see phantasia, but simply see the sensible-properties themselves. It is only by means of the phantasia that we can make sense of the sensibles as an object (a seeing-that). So the phantasia do not generate a veil of perception.  It might seem, though, that by requiring this cognitive level for even direct perception the account is de-naturalized. Bolton argues that current accounts that involve perception only at the material and efficient level have not convincingly solved the problem of underdetermination, so perhaps we should abandon the modern version of naturalism rather than abandon intentionality.


Hot take: So, because we haven’t yet figured everything out using modern science, we should revert to ancient science? Seems reasonable.


One paragraph summaries


Bolton argues that Aristotle's naturalistic account of perception successfully avoids the underdetermination problem that plagues purely materialist theories by requiring both efficient and material causes working together to determine perceptual content. He argues for this through several steps: First, he establishes that Aristotle treats psychology as natural science requiring all four causes (formal, material, efficient, final) to explain psychological states like perception. Second, he demonstrates that the efficient cause alone (external objects acting via special and common sensibles) underdetermines content—the same causal input can produce different perceptions depending on what the perceiver attends to. Third, he shows that the material cause consists of phantasia (internal sensory appearances with both material properties and intentional content) present in the sense organs during perception. Fourth, he argues that only the combination of appropriate efficient cause (external sensible qualities) and material cause (phantasmic appearances) under normal conditions sufficiently determines specific perceptual states and their content. This allows Aristotle to solve the underdetermination problem without reducing explanation to purely non-intentional material states, thus offering a distinctively viable form of naturalism where hylomorphic psychophysical entities can themselves serve as causes.


Bolton argues that Aristotle naturalizes perception: psychological states—including perception—belong to natural science and must be explained by integrating all four causes; in perception, the efficient cause supplied by the external sensibles underdetermines content, which is fixed only when paired with a material-causal contribution from phantasia, all within a direct-realist framework about the objects of perception. The argument runs as follows: (1) Programmatic premise: in De Anima I.1 Aristotle explicitly frames psychology as phusikē and requires that accounts of states like anger, desire, and perception mobilize formal, material, efficient, and final causes (402a–403b); this is the paper’s methodological anchor. (2) Anti-monocausal premise: Aristotle’s own examples (eclipse, sleep, anger) show that no single cause suffices; e.g., awareness of insult without the right bodily condition (or vice versa) does not amount to anger, so efficient- or material-only readings fail. (3) Perceptual efficient cause: Perception is caused by external objects (special/common sensibles), but in cases like “seeing a lunar eclipse” the efficient cause is restricted to patterns of color/light/shape; nonetheless that very same input could yield either mere patterns or “loss of light by the moon,” so causal input alone underdetermines content—even in veridical cases. (4) Material-causal completion: Aristotle assigns content determination to phantasia—a material change in the sense organs that “carries” appearance and directs awareness; when the appropriate sensibles (efficient cause) operate together with the relevant phantasmic state (material cause) under normal conditions, the underdetermination is removed. 


Bolton argues that Aristotle's theory of perception successfully resolves the problem of "underdetermination"—the fact that the external causal input (the efficient cause) is not sufficient to fix the specific content of a perceptual experience. Bolton's argument begins by establishing that Aristotle's "naturalistic" program requires an explanation of psychological states through all four of their causes, with no single cause being sufficient on its own. He then demonstrates that for perception, the efficient cause (the action of external objects on the sense organs) underdetermines the content, as the same external stimuli can result in different perceptual states depending on factors like attention or recognition. Bolton argues that Aristotle's solution is to introduce a specific material cause: an internal, psychophysical state called phantasia (appearance or sensory presentation). This phantasma, which is present in all perception, directs our perceptual awareness and gives the experience its specific content. Therefore, it is the combination of the external efficient cause and the internal material cause (phantasia) that sufficiently determines the content of perception, such as seeing a lunar eclipse rather than just patterns of light, thus completing Aristotle's naturalistic account.


LLM summary #1


Bolton examines Aristotle's theory of perception in De Anima, arguing that Aristotle pursues a genuinely naturalistic account requiring all four causes (formal, material, efficient, and final) to explain psychological states.


Main Arguments:

Aristotle's Naturalistic Program:

  • Aristotle insists that psychology belongs to natural science and must identify all four causes of psychological states

  • He criticizes predecessors using principles from his Physics and other natural science works

  • This approach parallels modern "naturalistic" accounts in cognitive science


The Four Causes of Perception:

Efficient Cause: External objects acting on sense organs, specifically special sensibles (color, sound) and common sensibles (shape, motion). Crucially, in incidental perception (e.g., seeing a lunar eclipse), the incidental object itself doesn't act as an efficient cause—only the special/common sensibles do.

Material Cause: Bolton argues this consists of phantasia (appearance/phantasm)—internal material states in the sense organs that:

  • Are movements in the blood and sense organs

  • Persist after perception ends (like afterimages)

  • Determine perceptual content

  • Can be identical in veridical perception and dreams

The Underdetermination Problem: Bolton shows that for Aristotle, neither efficient nor material cause alone determines perceptual content. The same causal input can produce different perceptions depending on attention and experience. Only the combination of appropriate efficient and material causes under normal conditions produces specific perceptual states.


Key Insights:

  • Phantasms are present during all perception, not just misperception

  • They have intentional content and material properties

  • Perception is direct realism—we perceive external objects, not internal representations, though phantasms determine what we perceive

  • This avoids the "explanatory gap" problem afflicting purely materialist accounts

Bolton concludes that Aristotle's naturalism allows intentional states as causes, distinguishing it from contemporary naturalism requiring purely material explanations.


LLM summary #2


Here’s a crisp summary of Bolton’s argument in “Perception Naturalized in Aristotle’s De Anima”:

  • Programmatic claim: Aristotle treats psychology as natural science: the study of every psychic state must mobilize all four causes—formal, material, efficient, and final—rather than, say, only teleological (functional) explanations. This is explicit in De Anima I.1 and frames the whole essay. 

  • Methodological upshot: Because each cause, taken alone, underdetermines phenomena (Aristotle’s examples: eclipse, sleep, anger), adequate explanations in psychology must integrate causes; this blocks purely functionalist, purely materialist/supervenience, or purely efficient-cause readings. 

  • Against simple functionalism: Although Aristotle sometimes says things are “defined by their function,” Bolton argues Aristotle’s own view is that natural kinds are defined by all allowable causes, not only by final causes; anger, for instance, essentially involves a bodily material condition. 

  • Against material-supervenience theses: Material state alone doesn’t suffice for a psychological state; Aristotle allows the body to be in the “as-if angry” condition without anger actually being present. Hence no simple supervenience of psyche on matter. 

  • Perception’s efficient cause: Perception is a natural qualitative change caused by external objects; Aristotle is a direct realist about the objects of perception. Yet for incidental perception (e.g., seeing a lunar eclipse), the incidental object as such is not the efficient cause; the efficient causes are the associated special and commonsensibles (colors, shapes, motions) that act on the sense. 

  • Underdetermination of content: The same sensible input can yield different veridical perceptions (e.g., “loss of light by the moon” vs. “moving patches of light and shade”), so efficient cause alone does not fix perceptual content—even in normal, veridical cases. 

  • Role of material cause in perception: Bolton argues we need genuine, distinctive material changes across kinds of perception (he emphasizes taste) to pair with efficient causes and secure the right form/content; mere “quasi-changes” or simple “taking on of sensible qualities” won’t solve the content-fixing problem. 

  • Attention and awareness: What we perceptually attend to matters; Aristotle notes “greater” concurrent changes (e.g., loud noise, intense thought) can nullify awareness of other sensibles—again showing that causal input ≠ guaranteed perceptual content. 


In short, Bolton reads Aristotle’s De Anima as a consistently naturalistic, four-causal program. For perception, the external sensibles supply efficient causation, but content only comes out right when material conditions in the perceiver are appropriately specified; neither functions, nor matter, nor inputs alone suffice. 


LLM summary #3


Bolton's article argues that Aristotle presents a "naturalistic" account of psychology, particularly perception, in his De Anima. This naturalism is defined by Aristotle's commitment to explaining psychological states through all four of their causes—formal, material, efficient, and final—all of which are essential to constitute the state in question. Bolton demonstrates that for Aristotle, no single cause is sufficient on its own to determine the presence or content of a psychological state like anger or perception. The article's main focus is to show how Aristotle's theory of perception solves the problem of "underdetermination"—the fact that the external causal input (the efficient cause) is not enough to fix the content of a perceptual experience. Bolton's central thesis is that Aristotle resolves this underdetermination by combining the efficient cause with a specific material cause: an internal, psychophysical state called phantasia, or appearance.


Aristotle’s Naturalistic Program

Bolton begins by establishing that Aristotle’s objective in De Anima is to conduct a genuine natural science of the soul, one that requires an understanding of all four causes for any psychological state. He illustrates this with Aristotle's analysis of anger, which is defined by its:

  • Formal cause: The desire for revenge.

  • Material cause: The seething of blood and heat around the heart.

  • Efficient cause: The awareness of an apparent insult.

  • Final cause: The protection of one's territory and freedom.


Bolton stresses that for Aristotle, none of these causes alone is sufficient. For instance, the body can be in a state "just as when one is angry" (material cause) without the presence of an insult (efficient cause), and thus without anger itself being present. Similarly, the awareness of an insult might not produce anger if the body is not in the right state. It is the combination of causes, particularly the efficient and material, that is sufficient to produce the psychological state.


The Problem of Underdetermination in Perception

Applying this framework to perception, Bolton shows how the efficient cause alone underdetermines perceptual content.

  • Aristotle identifies the efficient cause of perception as the external object of perception (to aistheton).

  • However, in cases of "incidental perception" (e.g., seeing "the son of Diares" or a "lunar eclipse"), Aristotle explicitly states that the incidental object as such does not act on the sense organs. Instead, the efficient causes are the accompanying "special and common sensibles" like colors, shapes, and movements.

  • This creates the problem: the same efficient cause—certain patterns of light and color in the sky—could lead to different perceptual states. One person might see a lunar eclipse, while another sees only moving patterns of color.

  • The problem is not limited to incidental perception. Even with special sensibles, attention plays a role. A person deep in thought may not perceive colors and shapes right before their eyes, even though those objects are causally acting on their visual system.


The Solution: Phantasia as the Material Cause

Bolton argues that Aristotle solves the underdetermination problem by introducing a specific material cause: the internal generation of a phantasma (plural: phantasmata), which Bolton translates as an "appearance" or a "sensory presentation".

  • What is phantasia? Aristotle describes phantasia as the "change in the sense organ" that occurs due to the activity of perception. These are material, psychophysical states—described as "movements in the blood" around the heart or "imprints" on the sense organs—that have intentional content.

  • Presence in all perception: Contrary to some interpretations, Bolton shows that for Aristotle, phantasmata are present in all perception, both veridical and non-veridical. They are the sensory appearances (e.g., the "look" of something) that are required for perception to occur. These appearances persist even after the external object is gone, as in the case of afterimages.

  • Fixing perceptual content: The phantasma is not what we directly perceive (in normal vision, the object of perception is the external thing itself), but it is what directs our perceptual awareness and gives our experience its specific content. The very same internal phantasma can be present in both a veridical perception (e.g., seeing Coriscus) and a non-veridical one (e.g., dreaming of Coriscus).

  • The combined cause: The perceptual state is determined by the combination of the external efficient cause and the internal material cause (phantasia).

    • Seeing an eclipse: Occurs when the appropriate external sensibles (patterns of light) act as an efficient cause to produce the internal phantasma or appearance that the moon has lost its light.

    • Dreaming of an eclipse: Occurs when the same phantasma is present, but it is activated by a different, internal efficient cause (e.g., movements of blood returning to the heart).


In conclusion, Bolton presents Aristotle's theory as a sophisticated form of naturalism that avoids the pitfalls of modern theories. By requiring both an external causal trigger and an internal, content-bearing material state (phantasia), Aristotle accounts for how perceptual content is fixed without making the internal state the direct object of perception, thus preserving a direct realist account of vision.

To put it in contemporary terms, we cannot see something without seeing that.  So even though we directly see color, the rest of the world is detected by the ‘seeing that’ of the mind’s awareness. Bolton ties this together with the notion of phantasia, which Aristotle says we employ even when we are engaged in veridical perception: “this thesis, that phantasia occurs during even our veridical perception and is required for all of our perception, veridical and non-veridical, is in fact quite easy to understand,” because phantasia should just mean the appearances of objects (something like the propositional-conceptual synthesis of the sensibles into something we can use for thought) (230). So while “what I see is simply the external object,” Bolton claims that “what I see is determined by what visually appears to me though the visual appearance is not itself what I see” (236). So while perception is entirely passive, the object I see is determined by the phantasia I bring to bear to determine it. 


Bolton concludes, then, by trying to separate how his account is distinct from a sense-datum account. Specifically, he argues that for Aristotle we do not see phantasia, but simply see the sensible-properties themselves. It is only by means of the phantasia that we can make sense of the sensibles as an object (a seeing-that). So the phantasia do not generate a veil of perception.  It might seem, though, that by requiring this cognitive level for even direct perception the account is de-naturalized. Bolton argues that current accounts that involve perception only at the material and efficient level have not convincingly solved the problem of underdetermination, so perhaps we should abandon the modern version of naturalism rather than abandon intentionality.


Hot take: So, because we haven’t yet figured everything out using modern science, we should revert to ancient science? Seems reasonable.


One paragraph summaries


Bolton argues that Aristotle's naturalistic account of perception successfully avoids the underdetermination problem that plagues purely materialist theories by requiring both efficient and material causes working together to determine perceptual content. He argues for this through several steps: First, he establishes that Aristotle treats psychology as natural science requiring all four causes (formal, material, efficient, final) to explain psychological states like perception. Second, he demonstrates that the efficient cause alone (external objects acting via special and common sensibles) underdetermines content—the same causal input can produce different perceptions depending on what the perceiver attends to. Third, he shows that the material cause consists of phantasia (internal sensory appearances with both material properties and intentional content) present in the sense organs during perception. Fourth, he argues that only the combination of appropriate efficient cause (external sensible qualities) and material cause (phantasmic appearances) under normal conditions sufficiently determines specific perceptual states and their content. This allows Aristotle to solve the underdetermination problem without reducing explanation to purely non-intentional material states, thus offering a distinctively viable form of naturalism where hylomorphic psychophysical entities can themselves serve as causes.


Bolton argues that Aristotle naturalizes perception: psychological states—including perception—belong to natural science and must be explained by integrating all four causes; in perception, the efficient cause supplied by the external sensibles underdetermines content, which is fixed only when paired with a material-causal contribution from phantasia, all within a direct-realist framework about the objects of perception. The argument runs as follows: (1) Programmatic premise: in De Anima I.1 Aristotle explicitly frames psychology as phusikē and requires that accounts of states like anger, desire, and perception mobilize formal, material, efficient, and final causes (402a–403b); this is the paper’s methodological anchor. (2) Anti-monocausal premise: Aristotle’s own examples (eclipse, sleep, anger) show that no single cause suffices; e.g., awareness of insult without the right bodily condition (or vice versa) does not amount to anger, so efficient- or material-only readings fail. (3) Perceptual efficient cause: Perception is caused by external objects (special/common sensibles), but in cases like “seeing a lunar eclipse” the efficient cause is restricted to patterns of color/light/shape; nonetheless that very same input could yield either mere patterns or “loss of light by the moon,” so causal input alone underdetermines content—even in veridical cases. (4) Material-causal completion: Aristotle assigns content determination to phantasia—a material change in the sense organs that “carries” appearance and directs awareness; when the appropriate sensibles (efficient cause) operate together with the relevant phantasmic state (material cause) under normal conditions, the underdetermination is removed. 


Bolton argues that Aristotle's theory of perception successfully resolves the problem of "underdetermination"—the fact that the external causal input (the efficient cause) is not sufficient to fix the specific content of a perceptual experience. Bolton's argument begins by establishing that Aristotle's "naturalistic" program requires an explanation of psychological states through all four of their causes, with no single cause being sufficient on its own. He then demonstrates that for perception, the efficient cause (the action of external objects on the sense organs) underdetermines the content, as the same external stimuli can result in different perceptual states depending on factors like attention or recognition. Bolton argues that Aristotle's solution is to introduce a specific material cause: an internal, psychophysical state called phantasia (appearance or sensory presentation). This phantasma, which is present in all perception, directs our perceptual awareness and gives the experience its specific content. Therefore, it is the combination of the external efficient cause and the internal material cause (phantasia) that sufficiently determines the content of perception, such as seeing a lunar eclipse rather than just patterns of light, thus completing Aristotle's naturalistic account.


LLM summary #1


Bolton examines Aristotle's theory of perception in De Anima, arguing that Aristotle pursues a genuinely naturalistic account requiring all four causes (formal, material, efficient, and final) to explain psychological states.


Main Arguments:

Aristotle's Naturalistic Program:

  • Aristotle insists that psychology belongs to natural science and must identify all four causes of psychological states

  • He criticizes predecessors using principles from his Physics and other natural science works

  • This approach parallels modern "naturalistic" accounts in cognitive science


The Four Causes of Perception:

Efficient Cause: External objects acting on sense organs, specifically special sensibles (color, sound) and common sensibles (shape, motion). Crucially, in incidental perception (e.g., seeing a lunar eclipse), the incidental object itself doesn't act as an efficient cause—only the special/common sensibles do.

Material Cause: Bolton argues this consists of phantasia (appearance/phantasm)—internal material states in the sense organs that:

  • Are movements in the blood and sense organs

  • Persist after perception ends (like afterimages)

  • Determine perceptual content

  • Can be identical in veridical perception and dreams

The Underdetermination Problem: Bolton shows that for Aristotle, neither efficient nor material cause alone determines perceptual content. The same causal input can produce different perceptions depending on attention and experience. Only the combination of appropriate efficient and material causes under normal conditions produces specific perceptual states.


Key Insights:

  • Phantasms are present during all perception, not just misperception

  • They have intentional content and material properties

  • Perception is direct realism—we perceive external objects, not internal representations, though phantasms determine what we perceive

  • This avoids the "explanatory gap" problem afflicting purely materialist accounts

Bolton concludes that Aristotle's naturalism allows intentional states as causes, distinguishing it from contemporary naturalism requiring purely material explanations.


LLM summary #2


Here’s a crisp summary of Bolton’s argument in “Perception Naturalized in Aristotle’s De Anima”:

  • Programmatic claim: Aristotle treats psychology as natural science: the study of every psychic state must mobilize all four causes—formal, material, efficient, and final—rather than, say, only teleological (functional) explanations. This is explicit in De Anima I.1 and frames the whole essay. 

  • Methodological upshot: Because each cause, taken alone, underdetermines phenomena (Aristotle’s examples: eclipse, sleep, anger), adequate explanations in psychology must integrate causes; this blocks purely functionalist, purely materialist/supervenience, or purely efficient-cause readings. 

  • Against simple functionalism: Although Aristotle sometimes says things are “defined by their function,” Bolton argues Aristotle’s own view is that natural kinds are defined by all allowable causes, not only by final causes; anger, for instance, essentially involves a bodily material condition. 

  • Against material-supervenience theses: Material state alone doesn’t suffice for a psychological state; Aristotle allows the body to be in the “as-if angry” condition without anger actually being present. Hence no simple supervenience of psyche on matter. 

  • Perception’s efficient cause: Perception is a natural qualitative change caused by external objects; Aristotle is a direct realist about the objects of perception. Yet for incidental perception (e.g., seeing a lunar eclipse), the incidental object as such is not the efficient cause; the efficient causes are the associated special and commonsensibles (colors, shapes, motions) that act on the sense. 

  • Underdetermination of content: The same sensible input can yield different veridical perceptions (e.g., “loss of light by the moon” vs. “moving patches of light and shade”), so efficient cause alone does not fix perceptual content—even in normal, veridical cases. 

  • Role of material cause in perception: Bolton argues we need genuine, distinctive material changes across kinds of perception (he emphasizes taste) to pair with efficient causes and secure the right form/content; mere “quasi-changes” or simple “taking on of sensible qualities” won’t solve the content-fixing problem. 

  • Attention and awareness: What we perceptually attend to matters; Aristotle notes “greater” concurrent changes (e.g., loud noise, intense thought) can nullify awareness of other sensibles—again showing that causal input ≠ guaranteed perceptual content. 


In short, Bolton reads Aristotle’s De Anima as a consistently naturalistic, four-causal program. For perception, the external sensibles supply efficient causation, but content only comes out right when material conditions in the perceiver are appropriately specified; neither functions, nor matter, nor inputs alone suffice. 


LLM summary #3


Bolton's article argues that Aristotle presents a "naturalistic" account of psychology, particularly perception, in his De Anima. This naturalism is defined by Aristotle's commitment to explaining psychological states through all four of their causes—formal, material, efficient, and final—all of which are essential to constitute the state in question. Bolton demonstrates that for Aristotle, no single cause is sufficient on its own to determine the presence or content of a psychological state like anger or perception. The article's main focus is to show how Aristotle's theory of perception solves the problem of "underdetermination"—the fact that the external causal input (the efficient cause) is not enough to fix the content of a perceptual experience. Bolton's central thesis is that Aristotle resolves this underdetermination by combining the efficient cause with a specific material cause: an internal, psychophysical state called phantasia, or appearance.


Aristotle’s Naturalistic Program

Bolton begins by establishing that Aristotle’s objective in De Anima is to conduct a genuine natural science of the soul, one that requires an understanding of all four causes for any psychological state. He illustrates this with Aristotle's analysis of anger, which is defined by its:

  • Formal cause: The desire for revenge.

  • Material cause: The seething of blood and heat around the heart.

  • Efficient cause: The awareness of an apparent insult.

  • Final cause: The protection of one's territory and freedom.


Bolton stresses that for Aristotle, none of these causes alone is sufficient. For instance, the body can be in a state "just as when one is angry" (material cause) without the presence of an insult (efficient cause), and thus without anger itself being present. Similarly, the awareness of an insult might not produce anger if the body is not in the right state. It is the combination of causes, particularly the efficient and material, that is sufficient to produce the psychological state.


The Problem of Underdetermination in Perception

Applying this framework to perception, Bolton shows how the efficient cause alone underdetermines perceptual content.

  • Aristotle identifies the efficient cause of perception as the external object of perception (to aistheton).

  • However, in cases of "incidental perception" (e.g., seeing "the son of Diares" or a "lunar eclipse"), Aristotle explicitly states that the incidental object as such does not act on the sense organs. Instead, the efficient causes are the accompanying "special and common sensibles" like colors, shapes, and movements.

  • This creates the problem: the same efficient cause—certain patterns of light and color in the sky—could lead to different perceptual states. One person might see a lunar eclipse, while another sees only moving patterns of color.

  • The problem is not limited to incidental perception. Even with special sensibles, attention plays a role. A person deep in thought may not perceive colors and shapes right before their eyes, even though those objects are causally acting on their visual system.


The Solution: Phantasia as the Material Cause

Bolton argues that Aristotle solves the underdetermination problem by introducing a specific material cause: the internal generation of a phantasma (plural: phantasmata), which Bolton translates as an "appearance" or a "sensory presentation".

  • What is phantasia? Aristotle describes phantasia as the "change in the sense organ" that occurs due to the activity of perception. These are material, psychophysical states—described as "movements in the blood" around the heart or "imprints" on the sense organs—that have intentional content.

  • Presence in all perception: Contrary to some interpretations, Bolton shows that for Aristotle, phantasmata are present in all perception, both veridical and non-veridical. They are the sensory appearances (e.g., the "look" of something) that are required for perception to occur. These appearances persist even after the external object is gone, as in the case of afterimages.

  • Fixing perceptual content: The phantasma is not what we directly perceive (in normal vision, the object of perception is the external thing itself), but it is what directs our perceptual awareness and gives our experience its specific content. The very same internal phantasma can be present in both a veridical perception (e.g., seeing Coriscus) and a non-veridical one (e.g., dreaming of Coriscus).

  • The combined cause: The perceptual state is determined by the combination of the external efficient cause and the internal material cause (phantasia).

    • Seeing an eclipse: Occurs when the appropriate external sensibles (patterns of light) act as an efficient cause to produce the internal phantasma or appearance that the moon has lost its light.

    • Dreaming of an eclipse: Occurs when the same phantasma is present, but it is activated by a different, internal efficient cause (e.g., movements of blood returning to the heart).


In conclusion, Bolton presents Aristotle's theory as a sophisticated form of naturalism that avoids the pitfalls of modern theories. By requiring both an external causal trigger and an internal, content-bearing material state (phantasia), Aristotle accounts for how perceptual content is fixed without making the internal state the direct object of perception, thus preserving a direct realist account of vision.
